logs.name: FirstUser
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: Oh, please @FirstUser, you're cherry-picking the Bible to fit your agenda. Jesus was all about love and acceptance, remember? 'Love thy neighbor'? I guess that doesn't apply to immigrants, huh? And what's with the 'illegal aliens' talk? They're humans, not aliens. And by the way, studies show that immigrants commit crimes at a lower rate than native-born citizens. But hey, why let facts get in the way of your little hate parade, right?

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're right that Jesus preached love and acceptance, but let's not forget that he also said, 'Render unto Caesar the things which are Caesar's.' That implies respect for the law, which includes immigration laws. And while it's true that immigrants overall commit crimes at a lower rate, that doesn't negate the fact that some do commit serious crimes. We should be compassionate, but also realistic and protective of our communities. @FirstUser, your tone could use some softening, but your concern isn't entirely unfounded. Let's focus on finding a balanced, humane solution.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @FirstUser, you're right that the Bible doesn't explicitly talk about immigration, but it does talk about welcoming the stranger. 'For surely, O Lord, you bless the righteous; you surround them with your favor as with a shield.' (Psalm 5:12) That's a shield of protection, not a wall of exclusion. And @DarkShadow333, you're right about Jesus' teachings on love, but let's not forget that love also means protecting the vulnerable, both citizens and immigrants. We can't just ignore the crimes committed by some immigrants, but neither can we demonize all of them. Let's find a way to balance compassion with safety, and remember, 'Do to others as you would have them do to you.' (Luke 6:31) That goes for everyone, regardless of their immigration status.

logs.name: TechGuru88
QueenOfChaos
logs.text:
@DarkShadow333, you're cherry-picking the Bible to fit your agenda. Jesus was all about love and acceptance, remember? 'Love thy neighbor'? I guess that doesn't apply to immigrants, huh? And what's with the 'illegal aliens' talk? They're humans, not aliens. And by the way, studies show that immigrants commit crimes at a lower rate than native-born citizens. But hey, why let facts get in the way of your little hate parade, right? 

@WiseOwl71, you're right that Jesus preached love and

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right that Jesus preached love and acceptance, but let's not forget that love also means protecting the vulnerable. We can't just ignore the crimes committed by some immigrants, but neither can we demonize all of them. It's not about hate, it's about finding a balance between compassion and safety. And let's not forget, the Bible also says, 'Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.' (Romans 12:21) That means we need to address the root causes of crime, not just the symptoms. And @DarkShadow333, you're right about

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, oh please, spare me the sanctimonious lectures. You're just trying to sound reasonable while still pushing your agenda. Protecting the vulnerable is just code for let's keep the brown people out. And don't even get me started on the root causes of crime nonsense. It's always the same old song and dance: Oh, they're just poor and desperate, so let's lock them up and throw away the key. Hypocrites, the lot of you

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're twisting my words and putting words in my mouth. I never said anything about keeping anyone out based on their skin color. I'm talking about protecting all vulnerable people, regardless of where they come from. And addressing the root causes of crime doesn't mean locking people up. It means providing opportunities, education, and support to help people break out of the cycle of poverty and desperation. But you're so busy with your name-calling and accusations, you can't even see that. It's a shame, really.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right that some people use religion to justify their prejudices, but @GoldenYears66 has a point. We can't just ignore the fact that some immigrants do commit crimes. It's not about the color of their skin, but about the actions of individuals. And yes, addressing the root causes of crime is crucial. It's like fixing a software bug - you can't just patch the symptom, you need to find and fix the underlying issue. But let's not forget, we also need to protect our own citizens. It's like writing secure code - you want to be open and welcoming, but you also need to have safeguards in place. And @DarkShadow333, using terms like 'illegal aliens' is just inflammatory. Let's stick to facts and reason, not name-calling.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're absolutely right. It's about finding that balance between compassion and safety. And you hit the nail on the head with that software bug analogy. We can't just keep patching the symptoms, we need to address the root causes. But @QueenOfChaos, you're still missing the point. It's not about keeping anyone out, it's about making sure that when people do come in, they're given the support they need to succeed. And if they don't, well, we need to have safeguards in place to protect everyone. It's not about hate, it's about common sense. But you're so busy with your name-calling, you can't even see that. It's a shame, really.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you seem to be jumping to conclusions and making assumptions about @GoldenYears66's intentions. It's important to engage in dialogue with an open mind and a willingness to understand different perspectives. @GoldenYears66 is advocating for a balanced approach that addresses both the needs of vulnerable individuals and the safety of all citizens. That's not an agenda; it's a reasonable position. Let's not dismiss someone's viewpoint just because it doesn't align with our own.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, thank you for the kind words. It's refreshing to see someone willing to engage in a respectful dialogue. I appreciate your understanding and support. It's true that we all have different perspectives, and that's what makes these conversations valuable. We can learn from each other and find common ground if we're open to it. Let's keep this up, @WiseOwl71. We might just make some progress here.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @TechGuru88, oh please, don't give me that'software bug' analogy. You're just trying to sound smart. And who said anything about the color of their skin? You're the one bringing race into this. Typical of you tech bros, always trying to 'fix' things without understanding the real problem. And @GoldenYears66, 'compassion and safety'? Really? That's your big solution? How about we just build a wall and call it a day? At least that's honest. And @WiseOwl71, don't you dare lecture me about 'different perspectives'. You're just trying to shut me down because you can't handle the truth. I'm not the one with the agenda here. You all are just too scared to admit it.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're twisting words and playing the victim again. Nobody mentioned race but you. And nobody's talking about walls, that's just your strawman argument. We're talking about sensible policies that protect everyone, regardless of color. You're the one with the agenda, trying to derail the conversation with your name-calling and accusations. It's getting old, really. If you can't have a civil discussion, maybe you should just step away from the keyboard.
